analysis.summary: The Niagara Falls Water Board seeks a qualified engineering consultant to perform Phase 1 sanitary sewer evaluation survey (SSES) services in specified LaSalle sewersheds, produce an engineering report and corrective action plan for inflow and infiltration (I&I) reduction compliant with NYSDEC and Engineering Planning Grant requirements, and conduct post‑construction monitoring, with optional pricing for Phases 2 and 3.

requirements.description: Provide professional engineering services to perform Phase 1 SSES work in the 91st & Luick and 81st & Frontier 1 sewersheds, including all tasks 1–8 as described in Section 3.
Include in the proposal option prices, schedules, and scopes to perform SSES work for Phase 2 and Phase 3 sewersheds as described in Section 5.

Comply with all terms and conditions applicable to the Wastewater Infrastructure Engineering Planning Grant (EPG) and NYSDEC requirements, including the Engineering Report Outline for NYS Wastewater Infrastructure Projects dated October 1, 2022.
Identify a Project Manager as the primary contact person and provide ongoing project management and support, including data review, familiarization with the system, and meetings with NFWB and NYSDEC.

Conduct smoke testing in Phase 1 sewersheds, including providing all staff, equipment, and materials; resident notification; coordination with police and fire; weather-appropriate scheduling; and documentation/photography of defects.

Perform flow isolation and measurement (night-time weiring), including review of prior data, selection of adequate weir locations, provision of trained/confined-space-capable staff and equipment, resident notification, and analysis of infiltration in gallons per day per linear foot for each section.

Review and analyze NFWB-provided CCTV and manhole inspection reports for Phase 1 sewersheds, perform additional data collection as needed, and coordinate with NFWB on existing and additional CCTV footage and repairs performed.

Assess Outfall/SSO conditions for the two Phase 1 outfalls, including review of existing data, site visits, development of an assessment Work Plan, execution of authorized assessment activities, GIS-compatible documentation, and recommendations to reduce extraneous flows.

Plan and, if authorized, conduct focused SSES activities (dye testing, house inspections, additional CCTV) where I&I sources are identified, using a $10,000 contingency budget only upon NFWB approval.

Prepare a Phase 1 SSES report and corrective action plan satisfactory to NYSDEC, identifying I&I sources, recommending cost-effective corrective actions with budgetary costs and implementation timelines, and conforming to the Engineering Report Outline for NYS Wastewater Infrastructure Projects; report must be stamped and dated by a NYS-licensed Professional Engineer and completed in time for NYSDEC review early in 2023.

Conduct post-construction monitoring in 2024 of Phase 1 sewer improvements (assumed constructed in 2023), including pre- and post-construction flow and rainfall monitoring, and prepare a Post-Construction I&I Assessment and Cost Analysis Report for NYSDEC.

Proposal must include, at a minimum, sections on situation understanding; understanding of applicable regulations and standards; project approach, scope, and project organization; demonstrated experience on similar projects; experience and qualifications of subconsultants/contractors; specific experience of key project professionals; and schedule, effort, and budget breakdown.
Provide schedule in bar chart form and effort & budget in a spreadsheet task/hour estimate matrix with a not-to-exceed fee amount, including a $10,000 contingency for Task 6.
For Phase 2 option, provide schedule and fees to perform all applicable Phase 1 tasks in the 81st & Frontier 2 and 80th & Lindbergh sewersheds, omitting Task 5 (Outfall/SSO assessment).
For Phase 3 option, provide schedule and fees to perform all applicable Phase 1 tasks in the Mang & 88th sewershed, including Outfall/SSO assessment for one outfall.

Complete all forms in Appendix E (standard terms, conditions, and requirements) and return them with the proposal, including non-collusion, lobbying law disclosure, EEO policy statement, sexual harassment statement, addenda acknowledgment, and RFP acknowledgement and certification forms.
Attend the mandatory pre-proposal information session at the Wastewater Treatment Plant on the specified date and time.
Submit any written questions regarding the RFP by the stated deadline to the authorized Water Board contact via email, following the subject line guidance.
All proposer communications during the restricted period must go only through the authorized Water Board contact, complying with NYS Finance Law 139-j and 139-k (Lobbying Law).

Deliver sealed proposal package (one clearly marked original and six copies, plus one electronic copy on CD or USB) to the specified address by the proposal deadline; outer envelope must show proposer name/address and RFP number/title.
Proposal must acknowledge all addenda received or indicate that no addenda were received, using Appendix E Form No. 1.

Provide a detailed statement of qualifications including business structure, licensing, years in business, similar project experience with references, locations, key personnel, alternate business names, parent/subsidiary entities, debarment/default/bankruptcy/legal history, conflicts of interest, and details on any subcontractors performing more than 10% of the work.

Agree to the Water Board’s general RFP conditions, including rights to reject proposals, negotiate, waive irregularities, and award without discussions; explicitly list any exceptions in a separate “Exceptions” attachment.
Maintain proposal as a firm, irrevocable offer for 90 days from the submission deadline.

Provide adequate and competent personnel with appropriate licensing, education, training, and experience; ensure subcontractor personnel meet Water Board credentialing, safety, and security requirements.

Procure and maintain required insurance coverages (Workers’ Compensation, Disability, Employer’s Liability, Commercial General Liability, Auto Liability, Umbrella/Excess, and Professional Liability), naming specified entities as additional insureds on a primary and non-contributory basis, and provide certificates before work begins.

Agree to indemnify and hold harmless the Niagara Falls Water Board and related entities to the full extent permissible by NY law, and waive rights against the Board for damages covered by required insurance.
If requested, submit a Safety Program and Site-Specific Health & Safety Plan prior to commencement of work, and ensure full OSHA and applicable health and safety regulation compliance.
Pay prevailing wages as required by law and, if required, submit quarterly Workforce Employment Utilization Reports reflecting the workforce and salaries on the contract.

Submit monthly invoices with sufficient supporting documentation; comply with MWBE/SDVOB utilization and reporting requirements as a condition of payment; accept 60-day payment terms subject to undisputed invoices.
Do not charge state or local sales, franchise, or excise taxes to the Water Board; proposals must exclude such taxes.
Adopt and submit an Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Policy Statement meeting the minimum terms in Appendix E Form No. 4, and comply with all applicable non-discrimination laws.
Certify compliance with sexual harassment prevention requirements per State Finance Law §139-l and Labor Law §201-g, using Appendix E Form No. 5.
Certify compliance with the Iran Divestment Act, international boycott prohibition, MacBride Fair Employment Principles, and prohibition on purchase of tropical hardwoods, as described in Appendix E.
Disclose and avoid conflicts of interest; certify no improper payments or political/religious activities funded under the contract.

Maintain complete and accurate records for at least six years beyond the calendar year of creation; provide access for audit by authorized entities; support FOIL handling and confidentiality marking as specified.
Comply with NYS Information Security Breach and Notification laws (GBL §§899-aa, 899-bb; State Technology Law §208) if handling relevant data.

Comply with Mandatory State Financial Assistance Terms and Conditions for Non-Construction contracts funded with NYS financial assistance, including MWBE combined goal of 30%, SDVOB goal of 6%, submission of EEO Staffing Plan, Workforce Reports, MWBE and SDVOB Utilization Plans, Monthly MWBE-SDVOB Reports with proof of payment, and good-faith efforts/waiver processes.
Acknowledge that failure to meet MWBE/SDVOB goals without approved waiver may result in liquidated damages, breach of contract, or other remedies.
Certify non-collusion with respect to proposal pricing and competition, using Appendix E Form No. 2, notarized.

Complete and notarize the Lobbying Law Disclosure Statement (Appendix E Form No. 3), including disclosure of any prior non-responsibility determinations or terminations related to SFL §§139-j and 139-k.
Sign the RFP Acknowledgement and Certification (Appendix E Form No. 6), affirming the proposal as a firm offer and agreement to be bound by RFP terms and addenda.
Ensure neither the firm nor its subcontractors are debarred or ineligible under NY Labor Law §220-b or Executive Law §316 for suspension/debarment.
Accept contract termination provisions for cause, convenience, and for violations of SFL §§139-j and 139-k, as specified in Appendix E.
Recognize governing law (State of New York), venue (Niagara or Erie County courts), service of process, and no-waiver clauses as binding contract terms.
Meet MWBE Combined Goal of 30% (any mix of MBE/WBE) and SDVOB participation goal of 6% on the contract, or document good faith efforts and seek waivers as needed.
Submit MWBE and SDVOB utilization plans or properly completed waiver requests with the proposal, in addition to the requirement to submit them prior to contract execution.
Email the authorized NFWB contact to be placed on the RFP No. 2022-01 distribution list to receive timely updates and addenda.

evaluation_criteria.description: Demonstrated understanding of the LaSalle SSO context, regulatory drivers, sewershed prioritization, and project objectives, as reflected in the proposal’s situation understanding section. (Page 8)
Quality and relevance of firm and key personnel experience on similar SSES/I&I/SSO and NYSDEC/EPG-funded projects, including subconsultant qualifications. (Pages 6, 8, 15)
Degree to which the proposal includes all required sections, forms, appendices, option pricing, and addresses all required tasks and compliance items. (Pages 6, 8, 15-21, 27-35)
Competitiveness and clarity of not-to-exceed fees for Phase 1 and options, including task/hour matrix, contingency, and value relative to scope. (Pages 6, 8)

submission_requirements.format: Sealed paper submission: 1 original + 6 copies, plus 1 electronic copy on CD or USB (single PDF preferred), delivered to the authorized contact’s address; include completed Appendix E forms and MWBE/SDVOB utilization plans or waiver requests; outer envelope labeled with proposer name/address and RFP number/title.
sections_required: Situation understanding
Understanding of applicable regulations and standards
Project approach, scope, and project organization
Demonstrated experience on similar projects
Experience & qualifications of subconsultants/contractors
Specific experience of key project professionals
Schedule (bar chart)
Effort and budget breakdown (task/hour matrix, not-to-exceed fee, $10,000 Task 6 contingency)
Option 1 and Option 2 schedules and fees
Completed Appendix E forms (Forms 1–6 and other required certifications)
MWBE and SDVOB utilization plans or waiver requests

key_differentiators: Demonstrated deep understanding of NYSDEC Order on Consent requirements, R-value methodology, LaSalle sewershed prioritization, and the EPG Engineering Report Outline, showing the ability to align SSES work with regulatory expectations and deadlines.

A clear, innovative, and efficient technical approach to SSES (smoke testing, weiring, CCTV analysis, focused SSES, GIS integration, and post-construction monitoring) that goes beyond minimum requirements to optimize identification and reduction of I&I and SSOs.

Proven experience delivering similar SSES/I&I/SSO and NYSDEC- or EFC-funded projects in New York, with strong references, successful MWBE/SDVOB compliance history, and familiarity with EPG reporting and audit requirements.

A realistic yet aggressive schedule that enables NYSDEC review early in 2023 and supports construction in 2023–early 2024, with clear critical path, risk mitigation strategies, and coordination with NFWB operations.

Robust project management and communication plan, including a clearly identified Project Manager, structured stakeholder engagement with NFWB and NYSDEC, and thoughtful resident/public communication strategies for field activities.
Comprehensive and compliant MWBE/SDVOB strategy that credibly meets or exceeds the 30% MWBE and 6% SDVOB goals, with identified certified partners and clear roles, minimizing the need for waivers.

High-quality deliverables approach, including GIS-compatible outputs, clear and actionable corrective action plans with cost/benefit analysis, and well-structured reports tailored to NYSDEC reviewers.
Strong safety, confined space, and field operations capabilities, with well-documented Health & Safety Plans and experience coordinating with municipal crews, police, fire, and utility stakeholders.

evaluation_criteria.description: Demonstrated understanding of the LaSalle SSO context, Order on Consent, I&I and SSO issues, and project objectives. (Page 8, criterion 1, 20 points)
Relevant experience with similar SSES, I&I mitigation, NYSDEC/EPG-funded work, and qualifications of firm and key staff. (Page 8, criterion 2, 40 points)
Inclusion of all required sections, forms, technical approach, schedules, budgets, options, and compliance documentation. (Page 8, criterion 3, 20 points)
Overall cost competitiveness, clarity of not-to-exceed fee, task/hour matrix, and option pricing for Phases 2 and 3. (Page 8, criterion 4, 20 points)

submission_requirements.format: Sealed hard-copy package with one original and six copies plus one electronic copy (CD or USB) in PDF; include completed Appendix E forms and MWBE/SDVOB utilization plans or waivers; bar-chart schedule and spreadsheet budget matrix; clearly marked outer envelope with proposer name, address, RFP number and title.
sections_required: Situation understanding
Understanding of applicable regulations and standards
Project approach, scope, and project organization
Demonstrated experience on similar projects
Experience & qualifications of subconsultants/contractors
Specific experience of key project professionals
Schedule, effort, and budget breakdown
Completed Appendix E forms
MWBE and SDVOB utilization plans or waiver requests

key_differentiators: Deep understanding of the LaSalle SSO Order on Consent history, NYSDEC expectations, and the shift to R-value methodology, demonstrated through a tailored technical approach. (Pages 2–3, 8)

A clear, phased methodology for SSES, data integration (smoke testing, weiring, CCTV, manhole, outfall assessment), and focused I&I source identification that explicitly aims to exceed the minimum tasks. (Pages 3–5)

Demonstrated experience delivering NYSDEC-acceptable engineering reports that conform to the October 1, 2022 Engineering Report Outline, with examples of successful I&I mitigation and post-construction monitoring. (Pages 2–3, 5)

Strong project management and communication plan with a named, highly qualified Project Manager, clear coordination with NFWB staff, NYSDEC, residents, and public safety agencies, and proactive schedule management to enable 2023 construction and June 2024 post-monitoring completion. (Pages 3, 5, 7)
Competitive, transparent pricing with a well-justified not-to-exceed fee, detailed task/hour matrix, and realistic but efficient schedules for Phase 1 and options for Phases 2 and 3. (Pages 2, 5–6)

Robust MWBE and SDVOB participation strategy that meets or exceeds the 30% MWBE and 6% SDVOB goals, with identified partners and a clear plan for utilization and reporting, reducing the Board’s risk of non-compliance. (Pages 7–8, 36–43)

Comprehensive compliance posture addressing all Appendix E requirements, insurance, safety, prevailing wage, lobbying law, and data security obligations, demonstrating low contractual and performance risk. (Pages 15–26, 36–43)

Evidence of similar work in consent-order environments and with EPG or other state-funded wastewater infrastructure projects, including references, that shows ability to navigate regulatory, technical, and schedule constraints. (Pages 2–3, 6, 15)
